references.paper_title: powerlaw: a python package for analysis of heavy-tailed distributions
references.reason: Provides a crucial Python package used for the analysis of heavy-tailed distributions, which are central to the HT-SR theory that underpins the proposed AlphaPruning method.

references.paper_title: Rethinking generalization requires revisiting old ideas: statistical mechanics approaches and complex learning behavior
references.reason: Introduces foundational concepts of HT-SR theory, laying the groundwork for the analysis of model capacity and generalization performance using spectral properties of weight matrices.

references.paper_title: Traditional and heavy tailed self regularization in neural network models
references.reason: Expands the HT-SR theory by characterizing model training quality and generalization ability through analysis of the heavy-tailed behavior of weight matrix eigenvalue distributions.

references.paper_title: Heavy-tailed universality predicts trends in test accuracies for very large pre-trained deep neural networks
references.reason: Extends HT-SR theory to very large, pre-trained deep neural networks, providing empirical evidence of its predictive power for model generalization and connecting it to the concept of self-regularization.

references.paper_title: Post-mortem on a deep learning contest: a Simpson's paradox and the complementary roles of scale metrics versus shape metrics
references.reason: Further develops the HT-SR theory by highlighting the complementary roles of scale and shape metrics in characterizing model quality, emphasizing the importance of shape metrics for assessing the heavy-tailed structure of weight matrices and understanding model generalization.
